newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian T-bill yields slip in cash-poor market.
newsitem.headline: Russian T-bill yields slip in cash-poor market.

text.p: Yields on Russian government securities edged down in quiet trade on Friday in a market deprived of cash from banks, which had coughed up big deposits for the prominent Svyazinvest telecoms company auction.
Overnight credits, under strong upside pressure for several days, dropped as funds rolled in from the government securities market, dealers said.
*Average yield fell to 17.9 pct from 18.2 pct on Thursday
*Turnover fell to 3.35 trln roubles from 3.93 trln
*Central bank sold 79.0 bln roubles of T-bills
According to the terms of the Svyazinvest auction, bidders had to deposit $400 million to participate. Losers will receive their money back within three banking days.
"It is obvious that most people (bidders) deposited the funds in hard currency, and the money will not go to the forex market," said ING Bank dealer Alexander Lomakin.
"It is logical to suppose that it will be sold for roubles to be channelled into T-bills, while some of the hard currency will be used to buy MinFin bonds."

Russian officials said on Friday Cyprus-registered group Mustcom, set up by Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, Russian investment bank Renaissance Capital and others, won the Svyazinvest stake for $1.875 billion.
Overnight credits fell sharply as fresh funds from the T-bill market returned to the market. The rouble slipped until it hit a resistance level of 5,802 per dollar.

"Overnight roubles were practically free today, that is why roubles with today and tomorrow settlements opened at the same level," a dealer said. "Later, people started buying the dollar, but at 5,802, level sellers appeared."
